awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Liam T. Solus is "Combinatorial Convex Geometry of Real-Rooted Polynomials." The host institution for the fellowship is the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockhom, Sweden, and the sponsoring scientist is Petter Branden.
 
This award was supported with funding from the Office of International Science & Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the relationship between the properties of discrete mathematical objects, such as networks or permutations of a lists items, and their connections with geometric objects that generalize polygons in high dimensions.  Such geometric objects encode useful information about statistical models used in modern data science and artificial intelligence, and by associating discrete objects (like social networks) to them, we can learn new things about such statistical models and use them in new and interesting ways.  To do so, we need to understand how to relate such discrete objects to a geometric object and what kind of information each object encodes about the other.  This information is typically encoded using sequences of nonnegative integers

p0, p1, p2,..., pd,

which we normally represent with a polynomial

p(x) = p0+ p1x + p2x2 +...+ pdxd. 

We can call the polynomial p(x) real-rooted if, when we draw its graph, it crosses the number line d times.  It turns out that if the polynomial is real-rooted, it can provide us with useful information about the sequence of numbers p0, p1, p2,..., pd encoding information about our geometric object.  Consequently, a number of long-standing, unanswered questions in mathematics can be answered by determining whether or not a certain polynomial associated to a geometric object is real-rooted.  To do so requires that we have methods for proving that the polynomial p(x) is real-rooted.  One of the main outcomes of this project was several new techniques for this.  For example, one major result of the project states that a pair of polynomials a(x) and b(x) that can be associated to the polynomial p(x) will both be real-rooted whenever the places where the graph of

p(x)= p0+ p1x + p2x2 +...+ pdxd

and the places where the graph of the reversed polynomial

q(x) = pd+ pd-1x + pd-2x2 +...+ p0xd.

cross the number line fit together like links on a jacket zipper.  We applied this result, and several similar new methods for checking real-rootedness of polynomials to settle a number of previously unanswered questions in the mathematics literature.  In doing so, we were able to provide deeper insights into the relationship between certain families of geometric objects and their relationships with associated discrete structures.   These results have since inspired a number of new papers where others working in the field are now finding new and creative ways to apply the techniques introduced here to answer other questions within mathematics.

The second half of this project turns the previous story on its head: above, we described how real-rooted polynomials can encode information about a geometric object and its relationship with discrete objects like permutations or social networks.  It turns out that we can also use real-rooted polynomials to define geometric objects which we can then use to study important questions in statistics and machine learning.  A key example of one such statistical question comes from the realm of artificial intelligence.  In modern artificial intelligence, we are interested in designing autonomous systems that can collect data about their real-time interactions with the world and then use this data to make informed decisions about their actions.  In particular, such autonomous systems need to have an understanding of the cause-effect relationships that they might trigger or experience in the everyday world.  Hence, a fundamental problem in AI is to design efficient and reliable algorithms that an autonomous system can use to learn a cause-effect network for a system of events based only on the data at its disposal.  One of the major outcomes of this project was a new approach to developing such algorithms that rely on the geometry of objects defined by real-rooted polynomials and their relationship with candidate cause-effect networks given the available data.  Using this geometry, we were able to introduce one of the most reliable algorithms for learning cause-effect networks for observed data to-date.  We also extended these methods to give the first algorithm with reliability guarantees for learning refined cause-effect systems from a mixture of observed data and data produced after experimenting with changes to the system of events.  Each of these algorithms has since inspired new, follow-up research in the area that embraces these new connections to geometry. 

Collectively, this work has lead to a number of new international collaborations, as well as interdisciplinary collaborations.  In this way, the broader impact of the project goes beyond the technical contributions to the field and extends to developing a more connected mathematics community.  In addition to this, the research aspects of this project has also inspired a number of new teaching and outreach opportunities in which the PI worked to disseminate related ideas to university-level students going into the STEM industry as well as high school-aged students from underrepresented groups who are considering a career in STEM.
